Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the father should purchase it
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Requesting a signature upon delivery for moderately valuable items
Story: I glanced at the clock on my dashboard, my next delivery address blinking on the screen. My phone buzzed with a message from my wife: “Don’t forget, you promised Jamie the Nintendo today. He’s been waiting all week.” I felt a pang of guilt. Money was tight, but I’d scraped together enough for the console, hoping it would make Jamie’s birthday special. As I pulled up to the next house, I saw the package label—moderately valuable electronics, signature required. The customer wasn’t home, and I knew the company expected me to secure every delivery, no exceptions. If I left it, I risked a complaint and maybe even my job. If I waited, I’d be late picking up the Nintendo before the store closed. My hands tightened on the steering wheel. I could almost hear Jamie’s excitement, but I also felt the weight of my supervisor’s warnings about missed signatures. The pressure of being a good father and a reliable employee pressed in on me, and I sat there, torn, the minutes ticking by.
